resource.chars:
V and VI.

V <u>Of the Essential Characteristics of Orbitolites, and
of its relations to other Types of Structure</u>

64  If now we seek to determine the essential characters
of that type of organisation which is known under the
designation <u>Orbitolites</u>, we find them to lie in the presence
of <u>a series of annuli of sarcode</u> (and of corresponding
<u>passages</u> in the shelly disk) arranged concentrically
round a nucleus; each zone in the simpler type, containing
but a <u>single</u> annulus, so constricted at intervals as to form
a series of somewhat columnar segments (occupying the cells
of the shelly disk), connected with each other by narrow
bands of sarcode; whilst in the more complex type, each
zone contains two such annuli, including between them a
portion of its series of columnar segments, so as to constitute an
<u>intermediate</u> stratum, distinct from the <u>superficial</u> portions.
In either case, the segments of successive zones freely communicate
with each other by <u>oblique bands of sarcode</u> (also leaving <u>passagest</u> in the
